byline.contributor: Tim Arango reported from Baghdad, and Somini Sengupta from the United Nations. Safak Timur contributed reporting from Istanbul, and Gardiner Harris from Washington.
byline.original: By TIM ARANGO and SOMINI SENGUPTA

abstract: Obscure Kurdish militant group known as Kurdistan Freedom Hawks claims responsibility for car bombing that killed 28 people in Ankara, Turkey; Turkish leaders continue to lay blame for attack on Syrian Kurdish group known as People’s Protection Units, ally of United States against Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: The Kurdistan Freedom Hawks claimed responsibility for a bombing that killed 28 in Turkey’s capital, but Turkey’s leaders continued to blame a different Kurdish group, an ally of the United States.

headline.main: Obscure Kurdish Group Claims Hand in Bombing Turks
headline.print_headline: Obscure Kurdish Group Claims Hand in Bombing Turks

snippet: The Kurdistan Freedom Hawks claimed responsibility for a bombing that killed 28 in Turkey’s capital, but Turkey’s leaders continued to blame a different Kurdish group, an ally of the United States.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations
